title: The Committed        (The Sympathizer, #2)
author: Nguyen, Viet Thanh*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Perhaps the zaniest, most jaw dropping read I had in 2020, this book is now out (March 2021) and I'm finally getting around to ing it. The CommiPerhaps the zaniest, most jaw dropping read I had in 2020, this book is now out (March 2021) and I'm finally getting around to ing it. The Committed returns to the improbable life story of protagonist of The Sympathizer which not necessary but probably quite helpful to read that first (I did not read it and while I could have used some backstory sometimes I just let myself get swept into the current story). And it's essentially a dark comedy with smart, incisive observations about culture, politics, religion, war, colonialism, identity, masculinity, race relations, in France, Vietnam, and the U.S... I found myself laughing out loud, nodding ferociously, smirking and marking down lines. Like we get:That night my aunt and I smoked the finest hashish and drank the finest Haut-Medoc and listened to the finest American jazz, that black-and-blue music so beloved by the French partially because every sweet note reminded them of American racism, which conveniently let them forget their own racismAndThe most difficult thing, when offered two false choices, was imagining a third choice, withheld deliberately or otherwise. This was the most basic lesson of the dialectic, the swing between thesis and antithesis that allowed one to reach a synthesis. Whether the thesis or the antithesis was communism or anticommunism, the point was that they composed the polar opposites of what the West unironically called the Cold War, as fought between the USA and USSR. But the synthesis was the recognition that this war had been extremely hot for us Asians, and Africans, and Latin Americans. Seeing the failures of both communism and anticommunism, I chose nothing…There was a 5 page discussion of the infinite orifice of the toilet and anus, there was seemingly 20 pages full stream of consciousness no breaks or punctuation violent altercation that was so strange and yet so authentic to what it might be like to be in the fight (or at least for our highly frenetically thinking protagonist)... WEIRD but also well done? There are so many layers of interaction between individuals and nations that are in the whirling narrative of The Committed, and it can give you whiplash how many ideas are being thrown at you amidst the series of unfortunate events and super strange set pieces Nguyen is setting up. This is a book that requires completely surrender: you give yourself over to Nguyen's brain and words and settle into the guise of our protagonist, or you'll find yourself highly confused and need to reorient constantly.I think Nguyen is a hell of a writer - he has shown quite a range across his novels and short stories - although he can fixate and get repetitive at times, and the emotional impact he (I think) intended seemed blunted in comparison to the literary tricks, intellectual bits, and wordplay games. But overall this was fun, freewheeling and thought provoking. I LOVED Nguyen's The Refugees (mildly uneven as a collection but with absolutely brilliant stories) but had started and dropped The Sympathizer (the squid sex turned me off and I wasn't expecting or appreciating at that moment the humor and breakneck, stream of consciousness narration). But my enjoyment of The Committed encourages me to try the first volume again. What an intelligent, bizarrely enjoyable time! Highly recommended to lovers of weird literary fiction that are willing to embark on a wild ride, 4 stars with fondness....more

title: These Violent Delights        (These Violent Delights, #1)
author: Gong, Chloe*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: These Violent Delights is a solid debut by Chloe Gong: there's pretty strong writing throughout and some intriguing characters and use and departuThese Violent Delights is a solid debut by Chloe Gong: there's pretty strong writing throughout and some intriguing characters and use and departure of the source material Romeo and Juliet. I'd probably be at 3.5 stars, but my final rating is 3 stars because while I liked it, there were a few things that didn't work for me (most importantly the romance) and I think this might have been a case of trying to do to much in one book. These Violent Delights is a retelling of Shakespeare's famous tragedy while also being somewhat a piece of historical fiction in 1920s Shanghai while also being a YA fantasy with supernatural l horror elements: I think if maybe only two of those things had been part of the focus, the pace would have been a bit better and other characters and ideas might have been able to be fully explored.Here's for me what worked, what was interesting if not fully developed, and where I think things could have been better.THE REALLY GOODThe Writing: Gong is a strong writer, and I found the narrative to be engaging, paced fairly well, and descriptive without being too purple or over the top (which I've found more often in YA than in some other genres). There are some things that might be overused - I think everyone is smiling, acting, or behaving "tightly" in this book - but Gong has a clear prose that helps move things along and makes it easy to read even when the book is at its most dense with ideas and plots.The Politics and Discussion of Colonialism and Racism: Gong does a great job laying out the physical space of Shanghai and how pieces of the city have been carved up by various foreign nations, and then how those lines are being blurred and redrawn in the 20s amidst a push by capitalists and communists from Britain, the U.S., and China. But she also tackles in small and large ways the colonialist project and white supremacy - Juliette's time in the U.S., her wealth and status and polyglot nature are still not enough to stop others from their "surprise" at her "lack of accent" or protect her from being viewed as other and spit at in the U.S., and meanwhile returning to Shanghai she's confronted with encroachment and the gobbling up of resources, space, and lives of the city in the name of foreign powers and capitalist and communist enterprises expanding their power and dominion. She is forced to confront and fight against these things at every turn but still walk a line to preserve her family AND somewhat behave in accordance with the customary view of women in 1920s Shanghai. Gong takes things further by adding critiques of colorism within Shanghai society - it didn't seem like a coincidence that Rosalind and Kathleen referenced to have "brown" skin and contrasting it with Juliette's "luck"to have been born white and pale because it directly ties into Rosalind and Kathleen's acceptance into the Cai family as somewhat in but also outside and lower ranked in the family and gang. Gong's ability to shed light on the appropriative, destructive and dehumanizing aspects of colonialism while also indict some of the racism within Chinese society is well done, especially considering everything else at play in the novel that this is worked into.THE GOODJuliette Cai: Gong gives us a badass heroine to root for in Juliette Cai, a bit of a departure from Juliet but in the most welcome way. This Juliette is fierce: she's the heir to the leadership of the Scarlet Gang and has to balance between those that recognize her birthright and those that might prefer following the lead of a male heir (Tyler/Tybalt who serves as a foil for Juliette, another welcome development and more on that below), so her smarts, knowledge and fine upbringing are always on display and she must use her ruthlessness and willingness to engage in violence to get what she needs or inspire fear and loyalty when challenged. There's maybe some things about Juliette that were written a bit flimsily - like the number of times she is coldly smiling and being polite and sweet while also shooting off verbal barbs, or the number of the times her viciousness and lethality is a surprise to those opposite her which seemed farfetched considering she's the heir to the gang AND has a repuation she cultivated that precedes her - but she's dynamic, complicated, interesting. And she feels and we feel her pull to be loyal to and save her family, as well as her love for Roma, and how she makes decisions to balance those two things is pretty compelling.The Cai Extended Family and the Scarlets: Tyler Cai and Kathleen Lang are two solid expansions or additions to the R&J storyline (in very different ways). Tyler is Tybalt, and he's definitely more along the lines of the Baz Lurhmann super violent Tybalt than the "West Side Story" retelling version of Bernardo. But while his violent, ruthless, creepy character is perhaps a bit reductive, Gong makes him relevant by setting him up as a foil not to Roma but to Juliette. Tyler is a direct threat to her status as heir: he wants control and power (and to a lesser extent to preserve the Cai family and their position in Shanghai), and eliminating or discrediting Juliette is the only way he'd be able to leapfrog her. So Tyler's actions and approaches to situations force Juliette into reactive choices and decisions, she has to stay one step ahead and when she doesn't, she has to pivot in order to stay on top (and stay alive). It doesn't necessarily make Tyler the most compelling character in his own right, but it definitely makes him an integral part of the narrative here and he adds to the dramatic tension well.Kathleen Lang is an addition - there's no clear link I could see between her character and an R&J role, especially since Nurse is mentioned - but is a great character in her own right as well as serving to show how those slightly lower in the Scarlet pecking order are affected by the politics and tensions in loyalty. Kathleen is trans and her family is related to Lady Cai, so she's part of the family but not fully and is somewhat of an outsider (which from her own perspective is doubled by being trans and guarding that fact from larger knowledge). She's willing to put herself in danger and seek information, and smart and interested in the churn of politics and society, but she's also calm, steady and kindhearted, a pacifist by nature. She's adapted and adopted traits from Juliette and Rosalind to get what she needs and to avoid detection when needed, but what she wants most is to live in peace: she plays the game to ensure her survival and a good life for herself. Kathleen and Juliette are perhaps closer than Kathleen and Rosalind, despite the latter being her sister and them being triplets. Juliette's automatic, easy acceptance of Kathleen and protection of her, not just of her being trans but of her being a Lang and not a Cai, forces Kathleen to grapple occasionally with loyalty to her cousin and loyalty to the gang, but ultimately synthesizing both: she wants Juliette as head of the family and gang, fear Tyler's reckless violence and hate as opposed to Juliette's calculated ruthlessness. I'd hope the next book has more Kathleen in it!We similarly get a good sense of the Cai dynamics as both a family and a gang, and how those two identities intersect. Rosalind especially makes reference to the insecurity of her and Kathleen's position within the family and the gang: they are Cais by association, related to Lady Cai who married into the family, not given positions of much prominence in the gang. For Rosalind there's a suggestion but no full development of tension with Juliette - Gong appears to be going in a different direction than R&J where Rosaline was Romeo's prior object of obsession without real love (although it's possible there's extra backstory there we'll get in the next book), and I'd guess (view spoiler)[Rosalind's fear, insecurity and tension with Juliette will either reveal her to be the spy for the White Flowers OR align her fully with Tyler (hide spoiler)] but that's probably to be seen in the next book. Gong's Cai family is secretive, powerful yet imperiled by these encroaching colonialist, capitalist and communist powers, and their loyalties and intrigue were handled well.WHAT DIDN'T WORKInstalove Disguised by Old Flames: I'm not sure if this is a YA trend or not (I just read another forthcoming YA book Lore with a similar romance set up that was similarly irritating) but grounding a romance in a previous connection between the characters, friendship to romance or just romance, ISN'T a replacement for showing us the strength and depth of that connection in the past OR in the present of the narrative! Just because the author has told us that they used to be in love, doesn't mean we as the reader feel or believe it. In the case of These Violent Delights, we are told many, many times that Roma and Juliette met as young adolescents or teens and got to know each other and fell in love, and then were separated by violent betrayal and distance (Juliette being sent off to the U.S.). But we really don't ever see their relationship or its development in the past. So in the present narrative, we see the tension and anger and confusion Juliette has regarding Roma, and yet by time the tension is overcome and the romance between them begins, it doesn't feel momentous or like an authentic development or something we as the reader have longed for or been rooting for, it just kind of happens. That's an unfortunate let down for a book that is a retelling of one of the more famous romantic tragedies in literature.What's all the more ironic to me is that the source material Romeo and Juliet is itself an instalove play, it may be THE instalove literary example. There's no build up, no past connection, we are at the Capulet party, Romeo sees her and we hop right into "Did my heart love til now?" and "Good pilgrim" and balcony scene of dreams. So Gong's choice to root the relationship beyond yet give us little showing of the actual romance and swoony mushy stuff whether in the past or or in the present a) departs from the source material in a way that adds no value and b) I would argue detracts because the romance here stands up so unfavorably to the play and ends up being even thinner and less believable instalove.Roma and the Montagovs: Relatedly to the earlier point, most of the novel is in the third person perspective of Juliette or the Cais, but Roma and his Montagov associates - most notably Marshall/Mercutio and Benedikt/Benvolio - have some chapters and POVs. Gong's choice is a great inversion from the play, where the Montague perspective and focus on Romeo is weighted more there, but it does leave us as the reader not really getting to know Roma and certainly not with the same depth and understanding that we get with Juliette or Kathleen. Which again impacts how much we care and are invested in their love story. The Montagov side characters are similarly given shorter shrift: the tense power struggle scenes that Juliette gets with Tyler are barely replicated between Roma and Dimitri and his father, and the creation of Roma's sister Alisa seems solely designed to imperil a Montagov for the sake of the monster subplot.The Ending / Splitting Into Two Books: The ending pretty much came out of nowhere IMO. Just as the romance seemed to be getting started and being shown to us instead of told, we hit the climax and seemingly history repeats itself (no spoilers). I did not know going in that this would split Romeo and Juliet into two books - I figured this was the start of a universe and new plots would spin off after concluding the R&J retelling here - and rather than being left wanting more, I was confused and irritated. Romeo and Juliet isn't Shakespeare's longest tragedy, it's of pretty average length, so cutting it in half and ending not on a cliffhanger but a weird pseudo resolution felt odd. And I think this had to be done because so many things were going on in this book that there wasn't enough room or it would stretch to 600 pages or something, but at least not expecting it going in, I was caught off guard in a negative way: my "where is the rest?" wasn't said out of desire or need to finish or I've got to see where this is going, but more akin to "huh, that ended weirdly and flatly."The Monster Subplot: So for me, the political machinations and discussion of the intersection of colonialism, racism, nationalism, sovereignty in 1920s Shanghai were EXCELLENT! The romance was lukewarm and not entirely developed. This monster subplot thing - which did tie into the politics and all - while being suitably creepy and exploitative, felt unnecessary and to me at least supplanted space the romance deserved and needed, but was occupied by these added fantastical elements. Had the fantasy/horror bits been taken out and the romance more fully developed, I think it would have been a stronger book AND a more interesting retelling of R&J.Ultimately for me with retellings, I'm looking at what the author was able to make their own, what parts of the original were emphasized and preserved or improved upon, and what original ideas, characters or settings were brought into the equation. These Violent Delights hits high marks in some places, especially in terms of representation (Juliette as a more fully fleshed out heroine, Kathleen as a transwoman secondary but still important character, the Cais being the focal POVs of the story) and the setting in 1920s Shanghai, along with the discussion of the interconnected politics and feuds based on nationality and ethnicity that go beyond the original Capulet v Montague dichotomy. But it failed to fully show or make me care about the romance and about Roma, and if you can't be invested in the star crossed lovers it's harder to fully invest in the book as a whole. I'll definitely be interested in Gong's future work especially if she moves into adult genres, and I might lightly recommend this to lovers of YA seeking own voices stories. Despite its flaws, it's readable and there's some good stuff going on, and I did like it. But I don't think I need or care to read the sequel....more

title: Black Sun        (Between Earth and Sky, #1)
author: Roanhorse, Rebecca*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I almost didn't read this book, and I am beyond happy I did. In a familiar tale of advance reader's copies, I had downloaded Black Sun two months I almost didn't read this book, and I am beyond happy I did. In a familiar tale of advance reader's copies, I had downloaded Black Sun two months earlier, randomly saw that my ARC was expiring and figured the cover looks cool, it's fantasy based on and featuring the indigenous Americas, I'll give it a go before it disappears forever from my app. When I got to the end of the ARC, I swiped and was disappointed, enraged: how could there be no more pages RIGHT NOW?!? Rebecca Roanhorse, you built this world, created these characters I increasingly came to care for or be very curious about, set all the machinations in motion, and then left me on the precipice of I don't know what but something EPIC? And yet, I was thrilled, satisfied, JAZZED. Black Sun... Wow, what a start to a series! I think my rating is probably 4.5 stars, but I rounded it up to 5 stars for being entirely impressed with and admiring of Roanhorse's craft, ideas, and world building, plus having so much FUN getting into this story and meeting these characters. And I don't often find myself desperately swiping my iPad hoping more pages will materialize at the end of an ARC, so the leave 'em wanting more test was met and blown away!The book is set on the Meridian continent (could have used a map in the ARC but I think it's in the print book and on the book's website) and is set primarily in Tova, the holy city home to Sun Priests, assassins, secret cults and a political and social tension between the elevated ministry of the four clans. A total eclipse of the sun, an auspicious time generally but here the springboard for prophecy and destiny to arrive, sets the mood of adventure and the consideration of the range of cultural, social, and religious views held by the peoples and societies of Meridian. The main POV characters Roanhorse follows - Xiala, Serapio, Naranpa (and a lesser extent Okoa) - are all moving through and to Tova and their choices, actions, desires put them on a collision course. Roanhorse invests her storytelling wisely: I can't entirely predict where over the course of the series alliances, allegiances, and interpersonal relationships may go, and those decisions really intertwine and drive the movements of the plot. Roanhorse gives us a wealth of detail about the world without too much info dumping, and has a clear and occasionally lyrical style of prose while being mostly straightforward and clear in her descriptions. I think one standout example was the bonding of Xiala and Serapio on their journey across the Crescent Sea. Roanhorse gave us some scene-chewing descriptions of sailing at night, life on board with the crew and spotlighted Xiala's Teek abilities and the myths and truths of Teek culture, but also laid out the increasing intimacy between the two and slow unfolding of Serapio's character. And any of the flashbacks to Serapio's training were ominous, deep, dark, helping us fill in gaps on the pseudo-legendary gone and yet not Carrion Crow cult and yet also providing tremendous pathos and understanding for Serapio.Besides the storytelling and world building, in a moment where diversity and representation in literature is paramount and prominent not only in the characterization on the page but also in the persons wielding the pen er computers and creating the work (and also in the bookselling industry itself but that seems to be coming slower), Black Sun to me stands out both for being a great example of writer and work diversity and representation but, more importantly, seemingly executed NATURALLY, easily, flawlessly. (I say seemingly not to minimize what I'm sure was a lot of labor on the part of Roanhorse). To some degree, Roanhorse's novel fits into the existing counter narrative demonstrating great fantasies CAN be set in worlds beyond those inhabited by tall, mostly blond but some brunette, white humans and elves with Latin or Celtic or whatever magic based systems. Black Sun places us in a fictional world based on the indigenous Americas and even if some elements are less immediately familiar to a casual reader of fantasy, as those tropes have been utterly absorbed into entertainment culture, Roanhorse is great at grounding the reader in things that may be new while not over-explaining or stripping down her ideas and concepts and making them palatable to that accustomed audience. She truly "shows" and doesn't tell. The other key point re representation that is done leaps and bounds better in Black Sun than I've seen elsewhere is expressing the spectrum of sexual and gender identity, as well as centering a POV on Serapio, who is blind. Characters simply ARE who they are, a range of pronouns are employed (xe/xir) with little fanfare and are seamlessly included. Roanhorse gives her subjects the space, freedom, time and attention to have the portions of their sexual and gender identities be brought up in the context of developing personality and plot, giving us representation without sacrificing storytelling. It seems as though in many cases in modern fiction, authors can be willfully or obtusely ignorant of representation and making characters homogeneously cis and straight and abled. As a counter, other authors confront this issue head-on which is laudable but do so in ways that could seem to diminish their characters: reducing them to stereotype, maybe filling a quota or checking a box, or writing the characters in such polemical ways it interferes with the narrative and storytelling. Roanhorse's characters, especially Xiala, Serapio, and Naranpa and Ikan and their relationship, are living beings where their identities are represented and representative and important their actions and motivations BUT they are and can be other things in the story. I haven't read anything by Roanhorse before, but I cannot wait to read the rest of her work. Black Sun is a bravura performance and I cannot recommend it highly enough to people who love fantasy but are looking for something different, new, fresh and executed at the highest levels of craft and quality. And I cannot WAIT for the next book, or a novella, or just a few sneak peek pages, or a blog post, or whatever Roanhorse provides us because THAT CLIFFHANGER!...more

title: Plain Bad Heroines
author: Danforth, Emily M.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Plain Bad Heroines is both a beautiful work of queer Gothic horror-romance and a hot mess of too many ideas, not enough execution; too much time sPlain Bad Heroines is both a beautiful work of queer Gothic horror-romance and a hot mess of too many ideas, not enough execution; too much time spent in the modern timeline with characters that were less interesting and leaving us wanting TOO MUCH more from some of the key figures from the 1902 storyline; too many invocations that call back to Jane Eyre's "Reader, I...": "Dear Reader" from our nameless narrator was fun at first, but it was overdone IMO and made the effect irritating and unimaginative rather than delightful with clever winks and nods. Danforth was extraordinarily ambitious and I give her tremendous credit for coming up with the multiple forms of media all surrounding each other in the novel: the book by Mary McClane that the Brookhants Plain Bad Heroines are moved by and the adults react to in various ways, the book by Merritt Weaver that explains (some of) the happenings of 1902 at Brookhants, and the modern movie script and attempted documentary behind the movie that Audrey, Merritt and Harper are all involved in creating or are being created by. There's an entire strain of thought in the book about girls and women defining for themselves who they are, finding voices and power and identity free from constraint of either 1902 or present day forms of oppression and silencing over women. I genuinely found some portions - especially in the sections that revolved around the Brookhants students or Libbie and Alex - to be beautifully drawn, giving us depth of character and the trials and tribulations of loving women set in 1902 and on a boarding school campus. And some of the bits of horror were EXTREMELY creepy and disturbing, so Danforth has a way with atmosphere.But it was uneven in terms of execution. Because the plot line jumped around in time and between the two timelines of book + movie Harper, Audrey, Merritt and 1902 Libbie and Alex (with some girls of Brookhants thrown in), it feels as though it takes a long time to get to the meat of what the happenings at Brookhants actually were, and even then there are so many ideas introduced but not fully explored I'm still not entirely sure what did or didn't happen and I definitely wasn't sure why. I personally was not interested in Harper Harper's movie star of everyone's fantasies or Merritt's acerbic, standoffish, jealous writer: Audrey was a blank slate and a bit of a cipher. So each time Danforth switched to the "present" day, I was irritated to spend time with this group of characters when we could have been immersed in the gothic horror and unfolding mystery and tragedy of Brookhants. And it didn't help that the narration device Danforth used made the whole book feel a bit YA to me: as mentioned above the narrator is too knowing and highlighting tragedies to come but in a way that felt sometimes bratty and obnoxious. The narrator wasn't enhancing my enjoyment of the story, but getting in the way of my immersion and drawing my attention in ways I didn't think were helpful, informative, or entertaining. And the ending... I would re-read it so I could actually figure out what was and was not happening, but that would be too much work for a book that I struggled to get through at times for what I imagine to be very little payoff: again, brand new ideas were inserted, characters suddenly became relevant with not enough backstory, and some of the mystery was stripped away in favor of other fantastical elements that I felt were less interesting choices by Danforth. (I'm being as vague as possible, dear Readers, to avoid spoilers but also because I was so confused and annoyed by the ending).I think I'm ultimately rounding up from 2.5 stars to be 3 stars because even with its many issues, flaws, and irritating qualities, this was a really original, interesting, atmospheric concept and Danforth was able to write some parts really well. I did really like a lot of Plain Bad Heroines, but the inconsistency, throwing shit at the wall ending, and too many ideas left without sufficient support made it hard to rate higher than 3 stars. I probably wouldn't recommend it to many people without giving a thorough breakdown of its strengths and weaknesses and I DEFINITELY would not read it again. But in keeping with the book, I'd love to watch a period piece miniseries or read more self-contained stories set in 1902 about Brookhants....more

title: The Well of Ascension        (Mistborn, #2)
author: Sanderson, Brandon*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: At the end of Mistborn: The Final Empire, the heist that sparked the revolution is over and a new world order emerged. A year later in this book, everAt the end of Mistborn: The Final Empire, the heist that sparked the revolution is over and a new world order emerged. A year later in this book, everything is going to hell in a handbasket.Middle novels in trilogies can be tricky: you’ve got to build on the success of the first book that set the scene and introduced you to characters and did exciting things; leave things ready for the last book where the plotlines and character progressions will converge and heroes will likely rise, fall, and rise again; AND be an entertaining, meaningful entry on its own, otherwise it’s filler with no meaning. The Well of Ascension is a pretty damn good sequel, a terrific set up novel for the climactic conclusion (why I am I even writing this , I must read The Hero of Ages: Book Three of Mistborn NOW!), and was enjoyable enough as its own thing.Here's the setup with no spoilers: the crew at the end of The Final Empire is back/still in Luthadel - Vin, Sazed, Elend, Ham, Clubs, Spook, Dockson, Breeze - and preparing to defend the city from, well, everyone. Meanwhile we are introduced to new or expanded characters who may be allies, enemies, or some mixture of the two, and there's a traitor in the midst. Oh and on top of that a few characters are hearing things, a few characters are seeing things, and the mist may or may not be killing people. How much more tension do we need? Add in the strain of interpersonal relationships, political intrigue, responsibility for the city's most vulnerable citizens, and still dealing with the death of Kelsier (I'm still not over it even though I love how Sanderson has his characters still wrestling with it) and the cult that springs up after him, and we've got a recipe for a dramatic, action and chatacter development packed, EPIC second book in this series.Perhaps the biggest surprise for me was how much I really enjoyed Vin as the heroine and loved seeing her growth in this book. I hadn't warmed up to Vin that much in The Final Empire as some of her teen angst and fear I found irritating, her romance with Elend I found boring, and her suddenly superpowered status I found predictable and boring. But in The Well of Ascension, Vin is still wrestling with who she is and wants to be, but she has more and more well-rounded personality, confidence, we see her testing the limits of her powers and confronting the multitudes of her nature as a woman and a Mistborn, and how to position herself - for her, for Elend and the city, for the skaa and people, for Kelsier. I had been worried that without Kelsier, I'd have less interest in the characters, but Vin became the reason I read and I finally appreciated just how great of a heroine she was. Elend I certainly enjoyed more in this book watching him grapple with having his ideals tested in reality and figuring out how to lead, but I overall preferred Vin's scenes with the kandra and with Zane to hers with Elend: I'm still not invested or interested in their relationship and I like the two of them better independently. Some of the new and expanded characters are interesting, and we get some time with them. The kandra (and yes I am being vague for a reason) was FABULOUS: fascinating development and really pushed Vin forward as a character, although I would have liked more space for the kandra as their own character too (but hopefully that's coming). Zane for me was a standout, another Mistborn in the mix, a flipside to Elend and a tension and connection with Vin, darkness but also mixed motivations and intentions. And to go a little spoilery and theory diving for a second: (view spoiler)[Zane is clearly not dead right??? His father thinks he is not, and he has that spike thingy in his chest (which was "God" talking to him, which I now think is whatever was trapped in the Well) that seems to be his weak spot a la the Inquisitors... is Zane some kind of hybrid Inquisitor-Mistborn, an Inquisitborn? (hide spoiler)]. Other characters I wished we had more time with - Allrianne I definitely thought was underutilized especially considering the mild twist to her character, but hopefully there's more to come with her story. And Breeze had some great moments in this book, a little less for Ham and Clubs but still present, but there was very little Spook or Dockson time unfortunately.There is A LOT going on in this book, and perhaps the reason I'm at 3.5 rounded up to 4 stars rather than 5 is because I think the pacing is a little off, and because certain plots are raised and then dropped in ways that didn't fit the characterization. In terms of pacing, I really enjoyed the political intrigues and Vin investigations, Sazed explorations, and Elend doing Princess Diaries Cosmere style with Tindwyl, but it definitely felt like the first half dragged a little bit. Once it hit maybe Part Three though, we were off like a rocket and I could barely put the book down as Sanderson pushed his characters and plots to their climactic conclusions and cliffhangers. "I AM FREE!" Most of the time those are words I'd love to read; here I am really freaked out to find out what exactly that means for our heroes. And then in terms of plots, I noted this earlier but in contrast to how well Sanderson had the characters reflecting on Kelsier's role in getting them to this point and navigating how they felt about the man and his mission now, there was almost no reflection AT ALL near the end of the novel after major character deaths (with one noteworthy exception). And yes granted there were constant hijinks and perilous threats still occurring (view spoiler)[Marsh where the HELL did you come from?!? Also pet theory linking Marsh and Zane that the spiked beings somehow have been commandeered or have to do with the free thing from the Well (hide spoiler)] but still, in the epilogue? Somewhere? They deserved that much at least. Another weirdly not dealt with element was (view spoiler)[Vin killing Zane and him being Elend's brother: so she kills him and then she and Elend just get married and Elend knows it was his brother and has almost nothing more to say? Even though he knew she had hid her following Zane and sparring with him and her being drawn to him the whole book? I mean, what? (hide spoiler)] and I didn't find Sanderson's resolution believable at all.BUT saving this from 3 stars IMO, this book does not belong entirely to Vin and Elend: it also belongs to Sazed. And for me, Sazed's incredible personal journey combined with uncovering the true mystery of the Well of Ascension was an absolute standout. Sazed has so many great moments, pushes himself to and past his limits as a Keeper and Terrisman, and then experiences so many and such deep losses in the book's climax... Sanderson really turned the pathos up and I FELT IT. Sazed's position as pseudo-steward, mentor and wise man from The Final Empire isn't dispensed with entirely but he is able to really grow, question, be more than what he was. And his fate at the end of The Well of Ascension along with what we've gathered about the Synod and the Terris people makes me think we are in for a brand new, bold arc for Sazed come the final volume. (view spoiler)[This is me guessing that Sazed is indeed the real hero of the ages (not that that prophecy is real necessarily) and will be going toe-to-toe with whatever came out of the Well and with the Steel Inquisitors who destroyed the Keepers, both out of duty but also as potentially vengeance for Tindwyl (hide spoiler)].At any rate, a really fun, slightly slow but eventually propulsive entry in the Mistborn series, heartily recommended, and I cannot wait to finish the series!...more

title: Mistborn: The Final Empire        (The Mistborn Saga, #1)
author: Sanderson, Brandon*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I think of myself as a fantasy lover and maybe even aficionado, and yet somehow I entirely missed Brandon Sanderson and Mistborn until my future bI think of myself as a fantasy lover and maybe even aficionado, and yet somehow I entirely missed Brandon Sanderson and Mistborn until my future brother-in-law gave it to me and said "READ IT". And I am really glad he did! He loaned me his copy of The Final Empire, and by the time I was flying through the last 100 pages, anxiously and excitedly flipping the pages and somewhat dreading the ending, I had ordered the boxed set from bookshop and am rapidly refreshing the shipping info so I can dive into The Well of Ascension expeditiously. I'm landing at a solid 4 stars: I really enjoyed this read and this felt like both a great standalone novel as well as a kickoff to an entire world I long to know more about, but it didn't immediately leap into my top, best-ever fantasy ranks, which is of course incredibly subjective. And since this book has been very well-covered with s, I'll keep my points shorter and hopefully explain what I loved and what I felt was perhaps a bit weaker, but still didn't diminish my enthusiasm.HIGHLIGHTSApproachability: Sanderson makes it SO EASY to dive into the world of Scadrial. I don't think I've read a fantasy novel that was written so clearly and straightforwardly while providing a rich atmosphere and for the reader an immediate context to the world we're encountering. Many fantasy writers employ language as either an added force or a crutch to their worldbuilding; while Sanderson does introduce a brand new system of magic that has its own vocabulary, the descriptive prose and dialogue is very straightforward and composed in contemporary English. I found this to be really compelling, as I can be someone who loves all the high fantasy ye olde language trappings, and yet I was very much captured and engrossed anyway.Magic: ALLOMANCY, it's awesome! A form of magic I never encountered or thought of, seemed entirely new, and it was well explained and shown off in ways that didn't involve too many paragraphs of exposition. Rather, Sanderson had Vin getting informal tutoring from all of the Misting masters in their metal of expertise, so we got more insight into their characters as well as some more dynamic, active scenes as Vin explores her powers. I always want to know more about the magic of given world, and it was great that within this first book Sanderson grounds us in the system but also paves the way for more in depth questions and mysteries to solve.Characters: Sanderson created some really fabulous characters in The Final Empire, and I was somewhat surprised just how much I cared for them and how quickly. For me, the shining examples were Sazed and Kelsier. I found Sazed to be my Uncle Iroh for the ATLA fans, A Terrisman and Keeper, filled with knowledge, wisdom, kindness, but also one of only a few of his kind and possessing vast and different power all his own that contains its own set of mysteries (view spoiler)[deepened by the revelations at the end of the novel (hide spoiler)]. And then Kelsier straddles the line between human/Skaa and Mistborn, man and legend, optimistic, daring thief and dark, haunted, murderous revolutionary BRILLIANTLY. I could not get enough of him, and that's a strong testament to Sanderson's ability as an author.Pacing: Sanderson knows when to pick up the pace, and DOES HE! Just when I was starting to maybe get a little antsy with all the balls and spycraft and Allomancy tutelage, Sanderson shifted the story into gear and suddenly we were hurtling into a multipart climax. And again his straightforward language here was an added benefit, calling up increased stakes and anxiety and horror and excitement of the situation and the characters readily and easily. The last third of the book I read at a breakneck pace to keep up with the atmosphere Sanderson had created, I needed to follow that pacing and know what happened!SOME MIXED FEELINGSPlot: This is maybe an odd flip side to my admiration for the pacing, but even while I was racing ahead to see what happened and appreciated Sanderson's twists and surprises, I was never truly surprised? I'm not sure if the plot is pretty basic/archetypal of fantasy or if I've just read enough of these books and watched films to make pretty educated guesses, but I felt like some elements were telegraphed early and maybe too often, so even though I couldn't wait to read it, I wasn't surprised by some of the plot developments. Even the mysterious little intros to each chapter, I unwound fairly quickly and correctly interpreted to whom they belonged and what it might mean. And at least one major twist/plot point, I saw coming very early and yet was hoping Sanderson would make like George R.R. Martin and "subvert my expectations"(view spoiler)[KELSIER, NO! WHY? ARGHHHHHH. Not only did I predict his death, but there were even enough breadcrumbs to not be surprised by how/why he planned it. So it was doubly sad/dispiriting. (hide spoiler)]. I could see it coming AND I understood the author's choice to move the plot that way AND it fits in with some of the traditional journeys of (especially young or teen) main characters in fantasy novels, but foreknowledge does not stave off disappointment and execution of the familiar plots is key. I felt Sanderson did this mostly pretty well, but it wasn't entirely satisfying or novel. Which leads me to my other main nitpick...Vin:. Don't get me wrong I liked Vin, she's complicated, feisty yet introverted, betrayed and yet able to heal and find faith and love in others. She has a backstory that we've gotten some degree of understanding of but also has many more mysteries surrounding her and I'm excited to explore more of those in the books to come, and she does have a pretty strong arc of growth even only in the first novel. YET I was not overly fond of the (view spoiler)[romance with Elend, who despite being bookish (yay) is as boring to watch as paint drying IMO (hide spoiler)], and the seeming speed and carelessness to which Vin approaches it/him seemed somewhat out of character, especially when juxtaposed her care and caution in coming to trust Kelsier, Sazed and the crew. And she is a teenager with a hard, broken past so I definitely gave her some space for that, but it could be wearying sometimes reading from her perspective which could be juvenile, petty, irritating, when we could have had more from Kelsier or Sazed or Breeze or even Clubs (more Clubs! I love his ability and crankiness) and Spook. And I LOVE a good heroine so it confuses me that I connected more or was interested more in the male characters, but here we are. (view spoiler)[And I'm just slightly trepidatious to go off adventuring with Vin as the focal point, I'm not sure her character is built enough for/liked enough by me yet and I mourn having Kelsier as a fantastic co-lead and older Mistborn foil to her role. (hide spoiler)] But I am still eager to take the next steps with her and see where Sanderson takes things!Ultimately, I recommend this enthusiastically for fantasy fans, and I am looking forward to finishing the trilogy and getting more of Sanderson's world!...more

title: Red Pill
author: Kunzru, Hari*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Red Pill is the second of Kunzru’s books I’ve read; White Tears was my first. And it is becoming a pattern in that I find it hard to aRed Pill is the second of Kunzru’s books I’ve read; White Tears was my first. And it is becoming a pattern in that I find it hard to assess and evaluate the novel and my reading experience after I finish Kunzru’s work, and also that my evaluation changes over time. I started writing this  mildly ambivalent about the book, enjoying its cleverness and meditations but feeling flat emotionally and left with a need for greater coherence and climactic payoff, but as I worked through my thoughts, my understanding and appreciation deepened for Kunzru’s craft, even of the things I liked less. The first half of the book for me was a bit less compelling for me and harder to read, but it was entirely necessary and the seeds planted sprout vines that descend throughout the text. We are introduced to the writer narrator, entering the Deuter Center for the writing fellowship facing a professional and existential crisis. The narrator is highly self-aware, and being in his head we vacillate between his selfishness, ego, insecurity, hunger for freedom, a heady mix that interacts with his depression and writer’s block. There are some interesting asides and anecdotes – the trip down memory lane into East Berlin and controlled life under Stasi was FASCINATING – but I could get wearied by some of the immersion into German literature and philosophy, although some of that was simply because I was less familiar with the references and it could break my focus to try and outside the text understand what was being referenced. One thing that I give enormous credit to Kunzru for in the first half is being able to slyly and obliquely plant thematic seeds in the first half that sprout in predictable yet still interesting ways in the back half. "Red Pill" as a title itself is spoiler to a degree, with all the modern, alt-right baggage that comes from the term and not simply meaning the ticket to freedom from its source The Matrix, but I appreciated that we could draw the lines from Kleist to Anton and the web woven round the narrator ourselves: Kunzru lays them out but deploys them softly rather than bluntly.The second half of the book starts by building on the groundwork of the plot and characters, and wrestles with concepts of masculinity and what it means to be a man, what space there is for men to experience depression, what men are or are not “allowed” to be, and and opens wider to some of the alt-right themes, although the way these ideas are dealt with could be a mixed bag at times. For example, there’s a recurring presence of a refugee father and his young daughter, who are held up as a foil to the narrator away at the Center and his own daughter at home. The narrator seems to focus on his failure to protect his daughter, and those feelings are magnified by watching Blue Lives, the aggressive cop show putting everyone in harm’s way and allowing horrendous violence and revenge to be taken by criminals and cops alike. Blue Lives is a fascinating device in and of itself – the cops are crooked and unsympathetic, yet have a code in which their violence is seemingly only exhibited on criminals and those involved in the underworld, while the brown criminals seem to be targeting civilians/women and children, though for the narrator it isn’t shown, just alarmingly and threateningly teased. Kunzru uses this as way to lead the narrator into Anton’s ideology and allow for being redpilled, that in this soft, modern world men have removed themselves from the primal and basic roles as protector and survivor for themselves and their families, and that in and of itself causes confusion and some form of illness that can be cured. And while the narrator rejects that in his head, it’s harder for him to refute in speech and the ideas (and Anton) takes some hold of him emotionally. But the father and daughter foil are less fleshed out than Blue Lives is for the narrator: these are simply brown, desperate foils with no ability to speak for themselves or in a larger way challenge the narrator’s assumptions, and I think that might have helped me appreciate the comparison AND perhaps on the plot side added to the unmooring of the narrator and demonstrate his further loosening hold on reality. Now, I know “comparison is the thief of joy” and all that, but I picked up Red Pill because I had had such an unsettling and memorable experience reading White Tears, and I was interested to see how another novel of his would work for me. I won’t get into explicit spoilers, although I think it’s somewhat less imperative in this case as there is seemingly less to spoil in the traditional sense. But Kunzru’s books, to keep things timely as Kunzru does, are in my view epitomized by the popular meme "they had us in the first half, I'm not gonna lie". There’s a divide for readers of White Tears as to whether the back half or third of the book makes or breaks the work, and I at least can see a similar thing happening for readers of Red Pill. For me at least, the second half is where Kunzru shows me WHY I am reading this book. This is where most of the grappling with his larger themes happen, where all the table setting of mildly boring details from the first half are woven in and pay off in dramatic and fantastical fashion, where Kunzru builds to a climax of ideas and action… except that doesn’t exactly happen in Red Pill. Or does it? The buildup is there and the mood is feverish and unsettling and thoughts are roaring through the narrator’s head and I read these pages in a similar fashion, but there’s not the same knockout punch at the end. Instead of the crescendo crashing over me, reading the end was more like a balloon being deflated. There was a letdown, a missed opportunity… and yet the more I think about it, the more I feel the deliberateness of Kunzru’s ending. That deflated balloon sound embodies the narrator’s disappointment in himself, his position in his new/old reality and how people are interacting with him. We go from the manic paranoia high of action and confrontation:The Apocalypse is the time when all secrets are revealed. By scrambling down towards the cliffs, I knew I was only postponing the moment when the bones of the dead would start up from the earth and I would be turned inside out like the victim of a medieval execution, my innards unspooled and put on display for the crowd. Privacy is the exclusive property of the gods. They see us, but we can never see them. We live like spies, always braced for exposure, while they remain a mystery. The sky was a helmet constricting my head; sweat dripped down my face. To:As I stand here at the kitchen counter and set out food for the party, I try to fill a bowl with olives normally. I try to open a package of crackers normally, to arrange a cheeseboard in the way a normal person should arrange a cheeseboard, without excessive precision or showiness, presenting the cheese according to some ordinary aesthetic standard, with the right level of care, neither too much nor too little, unwrapping the cheeses – a wheel of Brie, a wedge of Manchego, one of those expensive little goat cheeses that come wrapped in a vine leaf – just as a normal host would, someone for whom the meaning of these actions could never be in question.Despite the abrupt shift in tone, content, and pace, this passage really struck me and stayed with me, as it seemed to illustrate how the narrator finds even the most minute of tasks to be fraught with meaning and filled with traps that might show how not “normal” he is or is perceived to be. The scaring of people who love you, the fear and insecurity that then lurks in every interaction no matter how small, it’s a difficult space to occupy but even harder to get past or move on from. The emotional highs mirror the narrator’s own internal state, the ending is a letdown of sorts because that is where the narrator is and must be to function in the life he’s created for himself and wants. There’s a disturbing implication in there too, an unsaid question as to whether or not the redpill life isn’t in some way more free, more open, more amenable to emotion and interpretation and imagination. At one point, Kunzru takes the language of The Matrix and makes it even more present: the narrator explicitly thinks being home in New York to a technological construct (much like the bluepill world humans inhabit in the movie), which seems to compare negatively to the raw, lonely, “real” existence the narrator had on the island. And I think Kunzru’s intended or likely audience is able to of course reject that notion as the narrator does, but maybe push towards a less automatic and more examined idea of our choices, beliefs and the systems we subscribe to.While I didn’t love the placement in the timeline of the ending – (view spoiler)[ the election of Donald Trump and liberal fear and disappointment in the nation’s rejection of Hillary Clinton, a bit too on the nose if highly relevant to the topic  (hide spoiler)] - Kunzru ends on a note of both optimism and darkness, the narrator asserting his place in the world and his beliefs, while also acknowledging the fear and the danger presented. It's not much, but I can say that the most precious part of me isn't my individuality, my luxurious personhood, but the web of reciprocity in which I live my life.... Alone, we are food for the wolves. That's how they want us. Isolated. Prey. So we must find each other. We must remember that we do not exist alone.. For me, this book while not packing the wallop of White Tears, I couldn’t help but be impressed by Kunzru’s craft and was ultimately engaged and unsettled for days after. While I also was ambivalent about my feelings for this book, I think I will land on 3.5 stars, rounded up to 4 stars: this is a flawed book that I by turns found irritating and unsatisfying in parts, but Kunzru’s ability to tie it all together and keep me thinking about what I read speaks to its power....more

title: A Deadly Education        (The Scholomance, #1)
author: Novik, Naomi*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was bored to death, and I remain uneducated following A Deadly Education. I was unconvinced and not pulled in by the characters, cared little foI was bored to death, and I remain uneducated following A Deadly Education. I was unconvinced and not pulled in by the characters, cared little for the world Naomi Novik "built" through seemingly endless exposition, failed to feel like any kind of stakes or real fear/danger were set up despite the dark monster backdrop, and slogged with considerable effort through this read to get to the (mildly interesting with meh cliffhanger) ending. This is a 2 star read for me and that's probably even a generous one. I use the goodreads ratings description to rate books, and A Deadly Education was just ok, and it was ok like how eating a sandwich made up of two pieces of bread and a smear of butter is ok. If I’m hungry I’ll eat it and it’s edible, but it’s not a sandwich I like, love, dream of, crave, and it’s still a sandwich, just an unsatisfying one. My main issue is even though we are in dark magic school with dangerous monsters lurking about ready to devour, it feels as though NOTHING HAPPENS. Almost 85% of this book is exposition and info dumping. I wouldn’t even call it world building: to me that term invokes mastery and skill in weaving the details of the world into the plot, so we are learning about the environment in tandem with following the characters and their experiences; here it seemed like the “action” or what little there was of it would freeze and then paragraphs and paragraphs of backstory or detail would fill in. It was tedious and frequent, and it really inhibited my ability to immerse myself in Novik’s new universe.And maybe the long paragraphs describing some of the whats and the hows and the wheres of it all but not advancing the plot or characters much would be fine, if Novik had given us characters to pique our interest or let us truly feel the stakes of the story. But neither occurred. Even though we are in Galadriel/El’s point of view, I feel as though we never got to know her beyond her rude standoffish demeanor, hiding of her destructive powers, and irritation with the pseudo hero of the novel Orion Lake. Orion Lake is a sort of caring jock-ish invulnerable hero possibly hiding a secret all his own, but I was not MOVED or INTERESTED at all in what it might be. The classmates of El who orbit between enemies allies and maybe friends are lightly drawn and given minimal dialogue (what with the exposition taking up all the space). And let it be known that the so-called diversity trumpeted just feels like stand-in stock characters who are made to be ethnic minorities solely to say LOOK IT'S DIVERSITY, which I loathe. None of it felt authentic or meaningful.It’s also written in a manner that maybe made it harder for me to connect. It’s all first person from El’s perspective, so there’s teen angst and irritation and a breezy tone throughout. The problem is it just made it harder to engage and put a wall up between me and El, a hurdle to overcome to immerse in the world. I could at least read on the page that El had genuine fear of her powers getting out of control and of surviving another year, but I didn’t feel it... for a dark book about an undergoing school menaced by monsters there was very little in the way of atmosphere. I never really felt the characters dread or fear or eerie creepy feelings, or even their delight or power or sadness. It seemed like after every “dramatic” monster encounter they were all back in the lunch line and figuring out where people would sit in the cafeteria, a big whomp whomp. It was I suppose so regular for these kids to face and experience death that they didn’t emote much, but that didn’t make for very interesting reading overall. The predominant emotion was El’s disgust for Orion, a cover for sure for more complex emotions - we don’t really see but are told about - but it still permeated the feel of the read and threw me off balance.I might be one of the few ers thus far who knows Naomi Novik more from her very very long Temeraire series that kicked off with His Majesty's Dragon and stretched over a bunch of books (Uprooted has been on my to-read list for a mighty long time, and I'm not sure if A Deadly Education has hastened or destroyed my interest). While the Temeraire books were adult historical fiction meets fantasy, I stayed with the series for awhile until I discovered a sort of odd pattern past the first few books: one book of action, plot, and movement, and followed by one of immense info dumps and some character development but not a lot there there, plus a general decline in writing quality. A Deadly Education unfortunately falls into the trap that those less good Temeraire books are in: lots of ideas and maybe something cool in there, but little plot, little dynamism, and inspiring little feeling in the reader.To sum up again, it was ok. I went in with medium expectations - a dark school of magic, death and monsters lurking around the corner is a pretty easy sell - and endured an experience that let me down but in ways I couldn’t care less about. I was mostly bored and unsatisfied, I wouldn’t recommend it and I definitely won't continue the series BUT it wasn’t terrible and hopefully others will find the greatness in this book where I could not!...more

title: The Vanishing Half
author: Bennett, Brit*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: You could drown in two inches of water. Maybe grief was the same. And I think I'd add love to that list, Brit Bennett. I'm so overcome with the depthsYou could drown in two inches of water. Maybe grief was the same. And I think I'd add love to that list, Brit Bennett. I'm so overcome with the depths of my emotional response to The Vanishing Half, I think I've been drowned it its storytelling greatness and my love for this book.Full  to come, 5 stars of course and even that seems insufficient. But first, this biracial girl is going to stop crying, call her sister, hear her voice, rave about this book, and feel immense gratitude for having someone always to belong to and be part of me even as we make and recreate ourselves.-Now that I've had a chance to reflect and pass through the raw emotions this book prompted, I think I'll just dive straight into why this book hit me so hard, emphasizing the craft and technique that I admired, the force of the truths and observations Bennett made, and then the places I was most emotionally overcome. I've tried to keep things as spoiler free as possible and only refer to some major elements that occur in the early pages of the book: I didn't read any s going in and being uninitiated helped create that sense of magical discovery as I read. But if you like to know what to expect, I will hopefully shed some light!The book tackles really heavy issues in U.S. culture and in the Black community, some of which are now becoming more openly challenged (i.e. state violence against Black people) but some of which are still less familiar or thoroughly discussed outside of those places where the immediate damage is most prominently experienced (i.e. colorism). And for me, Bennett weaves these things throughout her story and indeed they animate the story, but they don't overwhelm the narrative: hers is a subtle hand despite the profoundly staggering effects of reading her prose about the lynchings of Black people and Black men most specifically, or the range of destruction created and caused by colorism.The trauma of violence rules against Black people hangs over all of the characters, their motivations and actions. Mallard is a town in Louisiana founded by light skinned Blacks, and at least some ancestors of the twins Stella and Desiree at the heart of the story were focused on continually intermarrying with lighter and lighter Blacks, making (in their devastatingly colorist verbiage) a more perfect Negro. A horrifying, wanton act of violence is visited on the twins' family early on, told in flashbacks that reverberate and echo throughout and inform how Stella and Desiree react to their town and plot their lives. For Desiree, it reveals the lie about Mallard, the idea that a lighter skinned Black person was set above and apart from other Black people, because none of that mattered when the white men came for him, so how could she care about lightness after that?. It pushes her towards finding new, broader ways to belong beyond the limits of pigment or shade that Mallard would enforce. For Stella, the same truth is exposed, but it is fear that drives her, a way to escape that and be free of the possible fate for Black people that awaited: a victim of violence at the hands of those with power for no particular reason other than they could. And that is tied of to the stark, insidious ways that colorism is in the fabric of society across place and time. Bennett shows its construction via white supremacy but also its pernicious absorption into the Black community, looking slightly different when employed across racial groups, but always exerting its ugly, false sorting and its weaponization. And Bennett demonstrates the illogic of colorism while still providing unanswered questions that provoked and gnawed at me when I read it, and still days later. For example, we're confronted with scenes of domestic partner violence, and at least of some characters reflect it's because Desiree disregarded the Mallard "way" of choosing light skinned partners and her husband, a dark skinned man, celebrated and resented her for her lightness and led him to beat her. But Bennett complicates this flawed analysis in a few ways: Desiree herself wonders if she fetishized Sam for his skin color, which is mirrored generally across people in the novel feeling attraction for those they are told not to be interested in, and Bennett explores how race and colorism influence and intersect with sexual and romantic attractions and interest. Additionally, Desiree feels some amount of compassion for him despite her refusing to stay and escaping with her daughter, as she puts it, thinking to herself: so he liked to throw his weight around a little. Who could blame him, living in a world that refused to respect him as a man? Finally throughout, Bennett makes a point of the intersectionality between race and gender. Desiree, Stella, Jude, Loretta, and other women of The Vanishing Half, are targeted in various ways because they are women AND because they are Black women, and they are preyed upon, harassed, subjected to the limitations of men white and Black, light and dark. The specific and collective trauma faced by Black women is too often unaddressed. Some of the truths and the questions that get raised by Bennett are uncomfortable or provocative, but should be spoken about and brought to light more, and even as it could be hard to read I appreciated all of the thoughts the book generated for me.There are as you might expect questions about what it means to be Black, to be white: is it self-identification, self-creation, is it blood and descent, is it what people see you as, is it what "fits" and you know or you don't? Stella the twin who vanished is the main fulcrum by which Bennett examines the various ways characters interact with what it means to be Black and white in the U.S. Desiree and Stella (and then later to a lesser extent Kennedy and Jude) serve as mirrors, both sets of mothers, daughters, sisters, cousins, longing and lonely, determining, deciding, and submitting to destiny where and who they will be. Bennett does this slowly, sometimes in more obvious ways - how Desiree and Stella each react to the births of their daughters - sometimes in more subtle ways - how Sam has to protect Desiree from angry youths in the wake of Martin Luther King's assassination and they cry together for the loss, both the specific and general, juxtaposed against Stella and Blake's chilly and shocked viewing of riots on the news, Blake framed as believing in a moderate country. What he wanted most, he always said, watching policeman club protestors on the news, was for everyone to get along. Brit uses mirrors and photography as ways to reflect how the twins have gone through processes of self-creation and growth, with some parallels later as their daughters consider themselves in mirrors, in photos, on stages, but for Stella and Kennedy there's a constant yearning for freedom and a cycle of continuous dissatisfaction and rebirth, whereas Desiree and Jude seek and find stability and create without drastic severance of self. Bennett doesn't land any one place but she gives you a lot of material to consider your own thoughts.There are so many small moments and turns of phrase that grabbed me, and were sly, funny, moving, enraging. And I truly felt enormous pathos reading about these characters, even and especially Stella, who was the most complicated, cruel and destructive, yet still managed to break my heart and have my heart break for her multiple times. And Bennett wrote this set from the 1950s to the 80s and 90s, but as our characters learn and know and we see daily, we don't escape our pasts easily and as a society and culture, we don't change rapidly and true freedom, inclusion, belonging comes extremely slowly. And yet Bennett's book, written and published before the murder of George Floyd, seems to presage how things can and do change. She writes: Important men became martyrs, unimportant ones victims. The important men were given televised funerals, public days of mourning. Their deaths inspired the creation of art and the destruction of cities. But unimportant men were killed to make the point that they were unimportant – that they were not even men – and the world continued on.. We're in a moment now where the formerly unimportant are important, where this dichotomy is turned on its head, where there's some equalizing of recognition and worth in death, and now all we must do is get that equality in our lives. The Vanishing Half won't tell us how to accomplish that, but at least for me it spurred discussion and deconstruction of my own ideas and beliefs, interrogation of intersectionality and understanding, while also giving me well-written prose to get swept away in and characters to root for while being sometimes aghast yet empathetic at their words and actions. And I really truly hope The Vanishing Half can give all of this to you too!...more

title: Piranesi
author: Clarke, Susanna
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: “The Beauty of the House is immeasurable; its Kindness infinite.” Piranesi is the book that got me back into reading, that reminded me of the bea “The Beauty of the House is immeasurable; its Kindness infinite.” Piranesi is the book that got me back into reading, that reminded me of the beauty of literature and how it is immeasurable, and its kindness and possibilities are infinite. Susanna Clarke’s Piranesi is a short - I read it feverishly in a few hours - but multilayered little novel that wound up being far more emotionally touching than I anticipated. I read Piranesi and found myself immediately discombobulated, lost and immersed in a world I had little understanding of. Clarke’s initial perspective, Filled with Odd and seemingly Random Capitalizations, helped to foment that feeling of being tossed upon rough literary waves. But similar to being caught in a riptide, I knew it was better to simply surrender and I started to float upon Clarke’s words, and let the narrative take me where she willed. And I suppose reading Piranesi at this time, when I myself am highly disconcerted, challenged, and full of feeling in an urgent moment in the world, the narrator’s strangeness and his World’s strangeness resonated strongly with me, as did his drive to understand and seek truth and justice or fairness. "‘Why a labyrinth, do you suppose?’…. ‘A vision of cosmic grandeur, I suppose. A symbol of the mingled glory and horror of existence. No one gets out alive.’” The book’s description is clear that a labyrinth is involved, and I won’t spoil anything about the plot specifically. But the novel is also a labyrinth, a massive puzzle in not so many pages, and Clarke has given the reader and the narrator a ball of string to ascend and descend throughout the layers of the work. Loss, loneliness, greed, power, devotion, subjugation, memory, perspective, imagination, reason, belief all swirl about as the narrator begins to follow the threads in the story and we the reader put the pieces together. "Perhaps that is what it is like being with other people. Perhaps even people you like and admire immensely can make you see the World in ways you would rather not.”I’ll also note I am enormous fan of Jonathan Strange & Mr Norrell: I read it annually and its beautiful use of language and detailed alternate history are two of the reasons I appreciate it so. These two books are in no way comparable, so I recommend you don't go in looking for Jonathan Strange pt II. Yet Clarke hasn’t lost her touch and is a great storyteller even in a wildly different setting. In Piranesi, we are treated to a simple, blunt, yet gentle narrative style, but with the fantastical properties that give the book a hazy, mythic feel throughout. It’s great craftsmanship to create the atmosphere, and Clarke knows precisely when to pierce it in the narrative. The mourning, exultation and calm the narrator experiences in later parts are amplified by this atmosphere, so that I as the reader felt these things for the narrator but also for myself as the read itself transformed.Piranesi is bold, beautiful, odd, and left me wanting a bit more while also feeling highly satisfied and eager for new literary worlds; and to revisit old ones. (view spoiler)[ There are more than a few nods to Narnia and The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe throughout, which if you’re familiar could cause you to solve some of the mystery a bit ahead of schedule. Perhaps the cutest and most obvious allusion was the narrator’s strong and innate affection for the Statue of the Faun in the House: I dreamt of him once; he was standing in a snowy forest and speaking to a female child. (hide spoiler)] I went with 4.5 stars and rounded to 4 stars because I’m not sure it immediately vaulted to my best of all-time list. But I’ll read it again, and we will see how it grows and changes in my heart down the line. And I know, as it’s written in the pages of the novel, once you have found the door, it is always with you. You simply look for it and there it is. Piranesi helped me open the door back up to reading and finding once again the humanity and catharsis and inventiveness in literature, and for that I will be forever grateful....more

review: Starting off 2020 with a great read! Kiley Reid's Such a Fun Age surprised me in the best way possible: it started off as an easy read, something I coStarting off 2020 with a great read! Kiley Reid's Such a Fun Age surprised me in the best way possible: it started off as an easy read, something I could flip through casually as Reid described the lives and worlds of Alix Chamberlin and Emira Tucker. About 1/3 of the way in, Reid's observant, conversational prose gave way for some incisive and darkly funny and poignant social commentary. Race, class, privilege, female relationships, who and what we love, how we choose to identify, build our narratives and those of others, how people navigate transactional relations that involve the most intimate parts of one's life... nothing is off limits for Reid and she deftly moves from each topic. But Reid's commentary never overtakes the narrative: I found myself caring more for Emira's and Alix's progressions, missteps, mistakes, and confrontations. I won't spoil things for future readers, but one highlight is how Reid builds genuine tension throughout the novel alongside her witty social commentary, highlighted best perhaps in the Thanksgiving dinner scene. I laughed out loud and cringed when Emira first entered the house and Alix's female friends swarmed her asking about if she was watching black-ish, and Alix's friend Tamra lightly upbraiding and acting as mentor by replying "Oh Emira, you have to see it. It's a very important show." The character of Tamra is an interesting prism by which Alix and Emira's different views and experiences are illuminated: Alix sees Tamra's presence at Thanksgiving as important, a chance to prove to Emira Alix's bonafides as a progressive, open-minded cool person, whereas Emira feels intense discomfort as Tamra questions her hair, her life choices, her cultural tastes: "She'd been to several events where another black party guest was foisted on her by a well-meaning but ignorant host, but Tamra appeared to be conducting this interaction on her own." There's also some clever observation of parenting styles at play - "A few bites into a strawberry rhubarb pie, Prudence began to have a breakdown about needing more whipped cream (this marked the third time, in Emira's opinion, that Prudence had reached number three)."- and all of this is occurring in the same scene in which Reid is building to the book's first mini climax, and will change the trajectory of Alix and Emira's lives after. It's really impressive stuff, made all the more so by how much fun it is to read.There's so much to like about this book, and I will say especially for female readers of color, there's even more to tease out and nod at and discuss with others. Reid doesn't draw hard conclusions about Kelley's potential fetishization of black women or how far from the tree Alix really did fall in how she created and imagined relationships with Emira and Claudette and these topics are rich for debate, but so is Emira's attempt to figure things out in terms of what she wants out of life for herself, not what her family or Alix or Kelley or Tamra believe she could or should do. There were things that resonated so strongly as a biracial female reader, and yet I never felt like Reid was inviting condemnation or judgment of Alix or Kelley and white characters: she let the narrative unfold and provided depth and revelations that brought context to their actions, and in the end I was pleasantly surprised by how much this book made me think, pause, reflect, consider all of the actors involved in the story.Overall, this is a disarming read, easy to finish and casually written yet sneakily strong and well-observed book. 3.5 stars, rounded up to 4 stars. Highly recommended!...more
